provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799-1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from the Butts collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 86 (11s., with lots 85, *Christ Giving Sight to Bartimaeus*, Butlin 420, and 87, *The Last Supper*, Butlin 424, to John Clark Strange); the dealer Francis Harvey, who offered the work in a catalogue of c. 1865; William Bell Scott by 1876; sold from his collection Sotheby's, 14 July 1892, lot 236 (Â£12.5s. to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); offered by Quaritch in his *Rough List* 127 of Aug. 1892, item 915 (Â£25); possibly acquired by Charles Eliot Norton and sold by him in 1923; possibly acquired by c. 1926 by the dealer Gabriel Wells; George C. Smith, Jr., by 1930; sold from Smith's collection, Parke-Bernet auction, New York, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 109 ($1200 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, probably acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); Rosenwald by 1939 and given by him to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1943.

objnote.p: The painting may have been restored in the nineteenth century, probably between 1863 and 1880. It was cleaned after its acquisition by Rosenwald in 1939.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based loosely on the Book of Job, 42:13-15. Job appears to be telling his story to his three daughtersâ€”an event of Blake's own invention. JobÌµan aged, bearded, and long-haired patriarchâ€” sits with three daughters (two at his side, one kneeling before him). Job and the daughters left and right sit on a couch with elegantly curved arms. His arms are raised slightly above the horizontal to point out the pictures on the room's walls. A rectangular wall picture appears above Job's head, with circular pictures behind his hands right and left. All three would appear to represent scenes in Job's own life. Job is telling his story visually. The upper group of pictures shows, from left to right, a group of figures with poles or spears and perhaps other figures huddled below them; God appearing to Job, his wife and friends; and a figure in the sky possibly raining lightning and flames on a plowman who bends sharply backward. Geometrical shapes decorate the floor of the room in which job and his daughters are pictured.

component.illusobjdesc: Jobð“´¼aged, bearded, gowned, and with long hairâ€”sits in the center of the design. His three daughters sit or kneel around him. He faces forward with his arms raised slightly above the horizontal. His extended hands, fingers slightly spread, point to the paintings on the walls. The palms of his raised hands face down. His legs are spread apart, with his bare right foot partly exposed beneath the flowing hem of his garment. His mouth may be slightly open, as he tells his story, and his knees are prominent.
Job and his daughters to the right and left sit on a couch with elegantly curved arms.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the left of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent. Her arms are bent upward and her hands crossed over her breasts. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the right. Her hair is long and a little curly.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the right of her father. She is gowned, with legs together and knees prominent. Her left arm may be bent upward, with her left hand touching, and resting on, her father's left upper leg. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the left. Her hair is long and a little curly; there may be a cloth of some sort, such as a scarf, over her head. Her mouth may be slightly open.

One of Job's daughters kneels or sits in front of her father. We see her from behind, but her head is twisted to the left and down. Her hair is long, with a bun at the back of her head covered by a (cloth?) net. Her arms are down at her side with her hands either touching or hovering just above the floor. The flowing hem of her garment is prominent.

The circular wall picture on the left includes at least two standing figures on the left with poles or spears (one spear point is pictured). The figure to the left may have one arm extended horizontally. There may be huddled or fleeing figures below. The scene suggests the destruction of Job's family.

God, with long beard and hair and arms raised horizontally, hovers, facing forward, in the wall picture above Job's head. Below him are huddled and contracted figures sitting or kneeling on the ground. These are probably Job on the right, Job's three friends (Bildad, Eliphaz, and Zophar) on the left, and Job's wife far left. Her long hair or a hood obscures her face.

In the circular wall painting right of Job, a man falls backwards, his right hand still grasping the handle of a plow. His head and body are dramatically bent backward, facing up and to the right, with his legs spread apart and his right foot on tiptoe. His right arm is bent sharply at the elbow. A building, possibly a house or barn with a prominent roof, stands far left. There may be a figure, with one arm bent upward, standing in a doorway(?) on the right side of the building. A figure with arms outstretched horizontally hovers above the plowman. This may be Satan or a vengeful god. Fire or lightning may cascade from his hands and below his head.
Job and his three daughters sit in a room with a circular back wall. The back wall is decorated with pictures; the floor is decorated with geometrical shapes.
